rename.from: Setting a custom parent directory for `TempDir`
rename.to: Provide support for setting a custom parent directory for @TempDir

body: Tentatively slated for 5.6 M2 solely for the purpose of _team discussion_

If your project requires you not to write to the default location of temporary files, you should set the `java.io.tmpdir` system property.

@rkrisztian Could you please try that?
Worked, thanks! I wish I knew about this. :)
Assigned to the general backlog and labeled as waiting for interest.

I'm also interested in this functionality.

In my case I only want to affect the parent directory of one `@TempDir` and therefore it does not make sense to use `java.io.tmpdir`.

milestone.description: Clean up a couple of the smaller, particularly not feature-related issues. Then ship 1.0.

issue.body:
The `TempDir` extension may or may not be thread-safe - it's hard to say because its tests definitely aren't (many static fields). The tests need to be made thread-safe, so we can then evaluate the extension itself. Right now, I see no reason why it shouldn't be possible to make it thread-safe (if it isn't already).

Also, can we change the name to `TemporaryDirectory` or something else that doesn't sound like letters cost actual money?

issue.title: Create new temporary directory/resource extension

labels.name: ‚öôÔ∏è component: Pioneer

issue.body:
After Marc Philipp implemented the `@TempDir` extension in Pioneer, it was later also added to Jupiter. It didn't (and as of September 2020 doesn't) support custom file systems, but other than that is more feature-rich than Pioneer's variant. This creates an unpleasant situation where there are two extensions that solve the same problem with the same approach, but slightly different feature sets (and an identical name to boot).

That said, there are a lot of feature requests for Jupiter's variant (‚ö†Ô∏è _some of these are already implemented!_ ‚ö†Ô∏è):

* [Multiple declarations of `@TempDir` in same parameter list or class declaration should fail](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2219)
* [Support @TempDir on constructor parameters](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/1754)
* [Introduce cleanup mode in @TempDir](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/1814)
* [Multiple @TempDirs should result in multiple directories](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/1967)
* [Provide support for setting a custom parent directory for @TempDir](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2088)
* [Support disabling cleanup for @TempDir](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2159)
* [Support custom file system for `@TempDir`](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2400)
* [Make `@TempDir` restore mint permissions before closing context to avoid `AccessDeniedException`](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2609)

After evaluating the situation in #277, we decided to remove the extension before the 1.0 release with the goal to look for a better solution to the problem in the future (i.e. this issue). So the task is to come up with a temporary directory (or, more generally temporary resource) extension that covers _more_ than what Jupiter does, possibly with an approach that makes different trade-offs (so users of Jupiter and Pioneer have more choices to solve their specific problem).

One interesting proof of concept to look at is @sormuras': [1](https://github.com/sormuras/brahms#temporary-directory-as-resource), [2](https://github.com/sormuras/brahms/blob/master/src/test/java/integration/resource/ChickenAndEggTests.java)

issue.title: Migrate tests to modern JUnit Jupiter

repository.name: impsort-maven-plugin
repository.description: Java import sorter plugin. Sort your imps!

issue.body:
The project currently uses the outdated JUnit 4.13.2. In order to make it easier to write tests and easier for future contributors to easily start working with the project, this path migrates the test suite to the modern JUnit Jupiter.

Changes:
- The `junit:junit:4.13.2` dependency was replaced with `org.junit.jupiter:junit-jupiter:5.8.1`.
- The `org.junit.jupiter.api.Test` annotation was used as a drop-in replacement for `org.junit.Test`.
- The static imports from `org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions` were used as drop-in replacements for the static imports from `org.junit.Assert`.
- `LineEndingEdgeCasesTest` was rewritten to use JUnit Jupiter's `org.junit.jupiter.api.io.TempDir` annotation instead of JUnit 4's `org.junit.rules.TemporaryFolder`.

issue.title: Resources extension: `TemporaryDirectory`: Allow custom parent directory
issue.body:
Consider introducing the ability to change where our `TemporaryDirectory` writes its temporary directories to. Currently it writes all directories to the filesystem path in the `java.io.tmpdir` system property. Users can adjust the property [in their build tool](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2088#issuecomment-574049472) or [directly in their tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2088#issuecomment-548325159), but the build tool approach isn't the most flexible, and the direct approach wouldn't allow the affected tests to run in parallel, I'd imagine.

junit-pioneer used to have a `TempDirectory` class with this ability, but it was removed because the built-in JUnit 5 `TempDir` was superior in almost every way.

This issue is a follow-up to https://github.com/junit-pioneer/junit-pioneer/issues/348 | https://github.com/junit-pioneer/junit-pioneer/pull/491.

Relevant JUnit 5 issues:
- https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2088

Docs for the old `TempDirectory` extension: https://github.com/junit-pioneer/junit-pioneer/blob/1415785e909f82066df2bd2b5ccfa10396aab0a0/docs/temp-directory.adoc

body:
in my case junit always set it tempDir to the working directory of the project. This is annoying because it always generates a mess into my source code directories.

Additionally this mess is not deleted after the tests were executed. I mean in this case this is good, because I don't want my source code directories to be deleted. Do you think I forget to configure something, or is this function as intended?

@bes1002t, are you using the `@TempDir` support in JUnit Jupiter?

If so, then the behavior you are describing sounds like a bug, and we would appreciate it if you would open a separate issue describing your setup and providing a failing example.
